channel.title: w
channel.description: When people saying making the packets from a array or make the packets to be safer so hackers wont hack the packets what do you mean when you say this?

item.title: w
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Literally nobody in this thread knows what they’re talking about.

If you want to counter cheat clients, you’ll have to be really protective with the way you handle packets, specifically item, object and interface actions. This means verifying everything the client, by doing things like keeping track of the interface the player has open, making sure the item exists on the ground before picking it up, and checking to see if the object really exists before treating the packet as if it does. You could also change the packet formats, which would be your best bet if you don’t want to do a lot of work.

Read full topic

[size=24pt]Anti cheat clients, rights?[/size][/quote]
he was questioning whether or not the op was looking for that and provided information towards that solution. the op never once said how the hacking is being done; ie cheat clients, packet injection, incorrectly sent frames, etc.

all im saying; dont go around calling people idiots, noobs, etc when they’re attempting to help. everyone needs to learn somehow, so simply point out something more informative towards the matter, or dont post.

its simple, really

item.title: w
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

[quote=“RiiPiiNFtW, post:15, topic:517914”][quote author=Vain_ link=topic=636177.msg4289290#msg4289290 date=1366927159]

[quote author=RiiPiiNFtW link=topic=636177.msg4289277#msg4289277 date=1366925208]

[quote author=Vain_ link=topic=636177.msg4289276#msg4289276 date=1366925123]
do you read? i was referring to you blatantly calling a user dumb for not understanding what the user said. at least he was trying to help?

the op was under the impression that packet handling via an array increased security, which was shortly corrected by yesteryear.
[/quote]I do read. I called the user dumb because he is. Adding a UID to a login has nothing to do with packet security.

Do you read?
[/quote]i do, actually.

you have no room to call a user dumb for attempting to help, but providing poor information.
simply correct them and move on.

[quote author=iz3 legend link=topic=636177.msg4289284#msg4289284 date=1366926055]
Enable RSA?
[/quote]probably a the best solution
[/quote]Don’t think you do. RSA is just a more secure version of UID, again, doesn’t provide any packet security. ISSACipher is what the user needs for packet security.[/quote]wat

What this does: RSA is an encryption algorithm put in place by Jagex to stop packet sniffers like autorune, which can fake packets, by hiding their isaac keys in the encrypted buffer, it made it impossible to decrypt the raw isaac cipher data. We shouldn't disable it for 2 reasons, it stops sniffing of usernames and passwords, and also gives isaac a purpose again.
RSA is an algorithm for public-key cryptography that is based on the presumed difficulty of factoring large integers, the factoring problem. RSA stands for Ron Rivest, Adi Shamir and Leonard Adleman, who first publicly described the algorithm in 1977. Clifford peniss, an English mathematician, had developed an equivalent system in 1973, but it was classified until 1997. A user of RSA creates and then publishes the product of two large prime numbers, along with an auxiliary value, as their public key. The prime factors must be kept secret. Anyone can use the public key to encrypt a message, but with currently published methods, if the public key is large enough, only someone with knowledge of the prime factors can feasibly decode the message.[1] Whether breaking RSA encryption is as hard as factoring is an open question known as the RSA problem.

how does that have anything to do with a uid

for clarification; rsa stops packet sniffing - isaac stops packet injection

Read full topic
